content.title: Supervised Exercise Therapy for Claudication
content.description: Structured, supervised exercise programs as first-line therapy for intermittent claudication, proven to improve walking distance and quality of life.
content.definition: Supervised exercise therapy (SET) is a structured program of walking exercises performed under medical supervision, typically for 30-45 minutes, three times per week for at least 12 weeks. It is recommended as first-line therapy for claudication and has been shown in trials to be as effective as or superior to revascularization for many patients.

program_structure: Progress intensity and duration over 12+ weeks
efficacy_evidence: Benefits comparable to angioplasty in many trials
barriers_and_solutions: Access: Limited availability of supervised programs
Insurance: Now covered by Medicare in US

clinical_pearls: SET is first-line therapy for claudication - before intervention
Walking to near-maximal pain is key to benefit
Supervised programs superior to unsupervised home exercise
Medicare covers SET - use this to encourage compliance
Benefits take 12+ weeks - set patient expectations
